meanings.definition: To displace or remove from a position or job.
meanings.sent1: The company decided to outplace several employees due to budget cuts.
meanings.sent2: She was outplaced from her role as manager after the restructuring.
meanings.sent3: The office prankster joked that he would outplace the boss and take over.
meanings.sent4: The new technology threatens to outplace many traditional job roles.
meanings.sent5: The storm's strong winds seemed to outplace everything in their path.

meanings.definition: To surpass or exceed in performance or achievement.
meanings.sent1: The young athlete trained hard to outplace his competitors in the race.
meanings.sent2: Her dedication and hard work helped her outplace her own expectations.
meanings.sent3: The student's goal was to outplace all previous records in the science fair.
meanings.sent4: The team's innovative approach allowed them to outplace the competition.
meanings.sent5: The singer's powerful voice never failed to outplace others in the music industry.
